Award.AwardTitle: Solar Cycle, Solar Wind, and Ultraviolet (UV) Control of Substorm Frequency and Magnitude
Award.AbstractNarration:
Magnetospheric substorms are one of the most widely studied and important topics in magnetospheric physics. Substorms are frequent and studies of substorms allow researchers to investigate the basic physics of the dynamics of the solar wind, magnetosphere and ionosphere system.
It is well recognized that magnetic reconnection occurs at the dayside magnetopause in the overwhelming majority of substorms and is generally thought to be the main way in which mass, momentum and energy are transported from the solar wind to the magnetosphere. However, other processes can also influence substorm dynamics. This is a proposal to evaluate the importance of the solar wind velocity and ionospheric conductivity on substorm dynamics. It is possible to separate these effects from the effects of reconnection because of the large 30 year data base created by the SuperMAG project. In a substorm the magnetosphere is first preconditioned by the solar wind. This preconditioning has two time scales. In this proposal it is hypothesized that those time scales are influenced by the solar wind velocity. One influence affects the reconnection rate at the dayside magnetopause and the other provides ?seed energy? to the plasma sheet. The investigators also propose to investigate the influence of ionospheric conductivity on substorm preconditioning by studying the effects of solar UV insolation. In particular they will investigate the semi-annual variation of geomagnetic activity with peak activity at the equinoxes and the observation that during substorms stronger auroras occur in the winter hemisphere. They propose to resolve the question of whether dipole tilt (and hence reconnection) drives the equinoctial variation or whether UV insolation is also important.
This work will support a young woman scientist just starting her career. The Applied Physics Laboratory has an ongoing program to support summer interns. The database from this study will be very valuable to the overall magnetospheric physics effort.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study made use of a new combination of ground magnetometer observations into a single data center, called SuperMAG, to study auroral substorms. Substorms are the well known dynamic curtains of bright aurora. SuperMAG makes use of over 300 magnetometers providing extensive coverage over the Earth's polar region. Several significant results were achieved. Over 50 thousand substorms were examined. One major result is that solar wind speed predicts the likelihood of a subsequent substorm far better than does the interplanetary magnetic field carried by the solar wind. 


There are three distinct types of solar wind structures: coronal mass ejections, high-speed streams, and slow solar wind. The occurrence of these solar wind structures depends on solar cycle. Further studies examined the effect of these different types of solar wind on substorm occurence. The occurrence of rate of substorms is, large during high-speed streams and during coronal mass ejections and small during slow solar wind. It was also demonstrated that negative magnetic bays (sharp decreases in the westward auroral electrojet index or increases in the westward auroral electrojet current system) are not associated with a substorm current system but directly driven by coupling to the solar wind. By examining the probability distribution for the amount of time between substorms, two different components were identified. One component is associated with external triggers, where a change in the solar wind or the interplanetary magnetic field triggers a substorm. The other is associated with a process internal to the Earth's magnetosphere. This result is to a certain extent consistent with some previous results, which show external triggers for the majority of substorms.
